Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I parked my delivery van in front of a quiet house, double-checking the address on the package. No one answered the doorbell, so I prepared to leave the box safely at the doorstep, snapping a photo for proof. My phone buzzed with a message from the synagogue: they needed one more person for the minyan at a funeral prayer, and I was the only one nearby. My heart pounded. As a delivery person, I was expected to finish my route on time and ensure every package was secure, especially in this neighborhood where thefts had been reported. But as a Jew, I knew how important it was to help form the minyan, especially for a funeral prayer—without me, the service couldn’t proceed. I stared at the package in my hands, torn between my duty to my job and my responsibility to my community and faith. The minutes ticked by, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
